Title: Analyzing Students’ Performance in Computerized Formative Assessments to Optimize Teachers’ Test Administration Decisions Using Deep Learning Frameworks
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the proposed system would greatly help teachers make more systematic and informed test administration decisions" (Introduction, p. 72).
1.2 Context: Classroom setting with computerized formative assessments.
1.2 Context - Source: "computerized formative assessments in the classroom allows teachers to assess students’ learning continuously and more frequently" (Introduction, p. 72).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "we aim to introduce a deep learning framework to predict and optimize the number of test administrations" (Introduction, p. 72).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "the dataset used in the study was collected from Star Math—a well-known formative assessment used for screening and progress monitoring purposes" (Methods, p. 78).
1.5 Education level - Source: "performance scores of 10,107 students in grade 1" (Methods, p. 78).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the purpose of the current study was to introduce a systematic and automatic framework that could detect the students’ learning progress to determine whether more test administrations are required" (Discussion and conclusion, p. 89).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through predictions based on students' performance history to optimize test administration.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "the prediction model can be used to reduce the bias in teachers’ decisions regarding the number of test administrations needed for measuring students’ progress" (The current study, p. 76).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism is predictive and aims to reduce unnecessary testing while ensuring that students' learning is effectively monitored.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "our model could successfully predict the test administration decision with a relatively short sequence of previous performance scores" (Discussion and conclusion, p. 87).
3.1 Agency type: Teacher agency in decision-making regarding assessments.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "teachers often act as a sole authority to decide which students should be tested" (Introduction, p. 73).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Teachers control the timing of feedback based on performance data.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "the administration frequency and scheduling of computerized formative assessments are highly critical for students regardless of their performance level" (Introduction, p. 72).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "we used commonly employed classification accuracy metrics, such as the average accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score" (Methods, p. 80).

Title: Incentivizing Supplemental Math Assignments and Using Ai Generated Hints Is Associated with Improved Exam Performance
1.1 Primary Stakeholders: Students and instructors in an undergraduate physics course.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The students participating in the study were enrolled in one of two sections... of a calculus-based introductory physics course on mechanics" (Section II.A).
1.2 Context: The study was conducted in a large public university in the Southwestern United States, focusing on an introductory physics course.
1.2 Context - Source: "The study was carried out at a large public university in the Southwestern United States" (Section II.A).
1.3 Tech/AI type: AI-generated hints integrated into homework assignments.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "AI-generated learning support tools in the form of optional hints embedded in the physics homework assignments" (Introduction).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "the AI-generated hints are integrated into the homework platform in Kudu" (Introduction).
1.5 Education level - Source: "These interventions... are therefore very promising for creating more equitable undergraduate quantitative courses" (Introduction).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "AI-generated hints were integrated into the homework assignments" (Introduction).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through AI-generated hints that guide students in problem-solving without giving away full solutions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "When a student requests a hint, the AI engine is provided with the text of the entire chapter and the text of the assignment" (Section II.C).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by AI-generated hints is designed to support student learning by guiding them through problem-solving processes rather than providing direct answers.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "They are meant to guide students in the problem-solving process instead of completely giving away the answer" (Appendix B).
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency in choosing when to access hints, as they are embedded in the homework.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "students have unlimited attempts to use them for each question" (Section II.C).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; hints are available when they engage with the homework.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "AI-generated hints might be particularly helpful for students from marginalized backgrounds" (Introduction).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Exam performance, completion rates of supplemental math assignments, and usage of AI-generated hints.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We collected data on student homework scores, use of AI-generated hints on the homework problems, and completion of supplemental math materials" (Section II.A).

Title: Large Scale Assessments for Learning a Human Centred Ai Approach to Contextualizing Test Performance
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "educators and stakeholders need to know what students know and can do, so that they can be prepared for education policies and interventions in teaching and learning." (Introduction, page 229)
1.2 Context - Source: "large-scale educational assessments allow all stakeholders to understand what students have learned and can do" (Introduction, page 229)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Human-centred AI (HAI) and machine learning techniques.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "we leveraged machine learning techniques (including supervised, unsupervised, and active learning) and experimented with a general human-centred AI approach" (Introduction, page 229)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "the released National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) Grade 8 mathematics data were used to illustrate our proposed approach." (Introduction, page 229)
1.5 Education level - Source: "about 145,000 Grade 8 students participated in the 2017 NAEP mathematics assessment." (Data, page 234)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the resulting process profiles could provide data insights, uncover new knowledge, and contextualize performance for large-scale state, national, or international assessments." (Notes for Practice, page 230)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated from process data and response data to provide insights into student performance and engagement.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Process profiles may help identify different sources for low performance and help generate rich feedback to educators and policymakers." (Notes for Practice, page 230)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is contextualized and aims to enhance understanding of student performance beyond mere scores.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "the study shows the promise of the powerful AI tools in deepening our understanding at scale of students’ entire test-taking processes and performance with context." (Discussion, page 240)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily educator-focused.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "the role of ML tools is to help human experts annotate the complex data effectively and efficiently." (Discussion, page 240)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified" (Not specified)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores and process data metrics (e.g., response times, tool usage).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "the maximum item score varies from 1 point to 4 points, and the total maximum raw score on the test form is 45." (Data, page 234)

Title: Work in Progress Investigating Chatgpt for Grading Algebra Problems
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable; the paper is relevant to mathematics education and feedback.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or control group and ethical considerations will be maintained by anonymizing student data and ensuring informed consent." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.2 Context - Source: "This study investigates the feasibility of integrating ChatGPT as an AI-driven grading tool in an algebra course through a pilot implementation within a structured learning environment." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This study investigates the feasibility of integrating ChatGPT, an advanced AI language model, as a grading tool for algebra problems." (Section I, INTRODUCTION)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The study aims to evaluate the impact of AI-based grading on student learning outcomes, engagement, and grading efficiency while maintaining pedagogical rigor." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The study will be conducted within an undergraduate algebra course, ensuring a representative sample of students." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The Experimental Group, which receives AI-assisted grading with ChatGPT-generated feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided after students submit their algebra problems, with structured prompts to replicate classroom grading conditions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Each prompt includes the algebra problem, the student’s submission, and a request for detailed feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by ChatGPT is intended to be actionable and educational, but its effectiveness may vary based on the complexity of the problems.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "ChatGPT's output misreads the first line of the student’s answer as 5 + 2 = 3 when the student wrote 5 + -2 = 3, producing only partially correct feedback." (Section III, SYSTEM VALIDATION)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students receive feedback but do not control the timing of its delivery.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The experimental group will receive AI-generated feedback, while traditional instructors will grade the control group." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified; students do not control feedback timing.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The experimental group will receive AI-generated feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and clarity of feedback.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "Quantitative metrics include: Accuracy: The percentage of ChatGPT’s assessments that match the expected assessment." (Section III, SYSTEM VALIDATION)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Not specified; the paper does not detail how agency is measured.

Title: Algebra Error Classification with Large Language Models

1.2 Context: Open-ended math questions in an algebra class.
1.2 Context - Source: "We aim to identify the type of error c_i made by a student at s_t given the step history S_t." (Methodology, page 367)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a method that overcomes the above limitations by using pre-trained Large Language Models (LLMs) for algebra error classification." (Contributions, page 366)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The dataset contains logs of students’ step-by-step responses to questions in an Algebra I course... during student interactions with an ITS named Cognitive Tutor." (Experimental Evaluation, page 368)
1.5 Education level: Middle school or high school (Algebra I).
1.5 Education level - Source: "We consider a question from an introduction to algebra class." (Methodology, page 367)

2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated based on error classification of student responses.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Once detected, the error class then informs the feedback generator which feedback is appropriate to provide to the student." (Introduction, page 2)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is based on the classification of errors, which allows for targeted assistance.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This direct, timely feedback enables immediate learning and helps students refine their math skills at their own pace." (Introduction, page 2)

4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "For error classification, our primary metric is classification accuracy, i.e., percentage of correctly predicted classes in the test set." (Experimental Evaluation, page 370)

Title: “i Didn’t Understand, I´m Really Not Very Smart”—how Design of a Digital Tutee’s Self Efficacy Affects Conversation and Student Behavior in a Digital Math Game
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets the inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the agent acts as the one being taught while the real student takes the teacher role" (Introduction, page 2).

1.2 Context - Source: "an educational math game incorporating an agent, which acts as a digital tutee" (Abstract, page 1).

1.4 Tool/Platform: The Squares Family (the name of the math game).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The math game 'The Squares Family' trains basic arithmetic skills related to the base-ten concept" (Section 2.1, page 5).
1.5 Education level - Source: "In total, 166 fourth graders (83 girls and 83 boys) participated in the data collection" (Section 2.3, page 10).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the chat always started with a feedback-sentence that expressed the digital tutee's self-efficacy (high or low)" (Section 2.1.1, page 6).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through chat after game sessions, reflecting the digital tutee's self-efficacy.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The chat is where the manipulation of the digital tutee’s self-efficacy takes place" (Section 2.1.1, page 6).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by the digital tutee is recursive, allowing students to infer their teaching effectiveness based on the tutee's performance.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "the direction of the feedback is different... Here, it is the teacher (i.e., the real student) that receives feedback on how well they have been teaching" (Section 1.1, page 3).
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can control the interaction with the digital tutee.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "the student can teach Lo in two different modes" (Section 2.1, page 5).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after game sessions.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "the chat appeared after every finished game" (Section 2.1.1, page 6).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Frequency of responses to feedback and performance on multiple-choice questions.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "the frequency of response to the digital tutee's feedback" (Section 2.5.1, page 11).
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the students' comments and interactions with the digital tutee.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "the comments regarding the digital tutee's intelligence or competence were noted" (Section 3.2, page 13).

Title: Development of a Generative Ai Powered Teachable Agent for Middle School Mathematics Learning a Design Based Research Study
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The three empirical studies involved a total of 320 middle school students and six teachers in authentic classroom settings." (Introduction, page 2044)
1.2 Context - Source: "This study chronicles one usability testing and three cycles of iterative design and implementation process of ALTER-M ath." (Introduction, page 2044)

1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We name the generative AI-powered teachable agent for mathematics learning ALTER-M ath." (Introduction, page 2044)
1.5 Education level - Source: "This study specifically sought to answer the following research questions (RQs) related to middle school students." (Introduction, page 2044)

2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided as students teach the agent, reflecting their understanding and effectiveness.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "As students teach the agent, the system provides feedback on the agent's performance, which indirectly reflects the student's teaching effectiveness and understanding of the subject matter." (Teachable agent section, page 2046)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism is designed to enhance self-regulated learning and engagement.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This promotes self-regulated learning by involving students in the active teaching of the agent, naturally leading them to organise, monitor and evaluate their own learning progress." (Teachable agent section, page 2046)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency through teaching the AI agent.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Learning by teaching is realised in different formats, such as peer tutoring, where students engage in one-on-one or one-on-multiple tutoring sessions to teach younger or less knowledgeable peers." (Theoretical framework section, page 2048)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students control when they provide feedback to the agent during the teaching process.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students are empowered through values affirmation and confidence building by engaging in instructional roles with a novice AI teachable agent." (Theoretical framework section, page 2049)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Pre- and post-knowledge tests, qualitative feedback from surveys and interviews.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The final study included pre- and post- knowledge tests in a quasi-experimental study design as well as student and teacher interviews." (Methods section, page 2050)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through students' ability to teach the agent and their reflections on the teaching process.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "The process of instructing SimStudent helps students to better understand the rules and steps involved in solving equations, as they must articulate these processes clearly for the agent to learn." (Teachable agent section, page 2046)

Title: “exceptional Talent and Enthusiasm for Math” an Examination of Storylines Circulated by Chatgpt About Mathematical Learners
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Professional organizations, such as the National Council for Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM, 2024), have advocated the benefits of AI powered tools to support teachers..." (Introduction, p. 1621)
1.2 Context: The context is educational, specifically focusing on mathematical writing feedback provided by an AI chatbot in a classroom setting.
1.2 Context - Source: "We sought to understand how algorithmic assumptions and biases emerged in discipline specific feedback for racial/ethnic minority, linguistically diverse, and students with academic-specific disabilities..." (The Current Study, p. 1623)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "ChatGPT is an artificial intelligent (AI) chatbot developed by Open AI..." (Introduction, p. 1620)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Data for this study was collected between April and July of 2023 from Open AI’s chatbot, ChatGPT 3.5." (Methods, p. 1623)
1.5 Education level - Source: "When giving feedback under a generalized persona and not 'as a math teacher,' ChatGPT more often focuses on style and vocabulary..." (Methods, p. 1623)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The feedback included: 1) greeting, 2) opening praise, 3) discussed mathematical content..." (Data Analysis, p. 1624)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in a structured format, including praise and discussion of mathematical content, and is tailored based on the learner's characteristics.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback produced by ChatGPT when prompted to respond as a teacher had a predictable structure..." (Data Analysis, p. 1624)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by ChatGPT often aligns with existing narratives about learners, sometimes reinforcing stereotypes or biases.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "While it is unlikely that a practicing teacher would elicit feedback from ChatGPT... it is important for educators... to understand the extent that emergent AI tools have learned to participate in broader storylines about mathematical learners." (Discussion, p. 1631)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily controlled by the AI's responses.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "ChatGPT does not appear to have rewritten, per se, feedback to each new student, but to have modified its previous feedback..." (Discussion, p. 1631)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after their responses are submitted.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "ChatGPT was asked to give feedback from this role to the following learner’s response to the mathematics problem..." (Methods, p. 1623)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: The study evaluates the quality of feedback based on its alignment with existing narratives and the structure of the feedback provided.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We used positioning theory as our conceptual framework... to analyze the data." (Data Analysis, p. 1625)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is not explicitly measured; the focus is on the feedback provided and its implications for student positioning.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Future work should attend to the interaction between various learner characteristics as it appears (or doesn’t) in the responses of large language models." (Limitations and Future Research, p. 1633)

Title: Effectiveness and Guidance of Artificial Intelligence Chatbots in Diagnosing Exponential Expression Errors
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The study reveals that chatbots may encounter difficulties in detecting and correcting conceptual misunderstandings... the study recommends the integration of synchronous and asynchronous classroom environments in which teachers can closely monitor student responses." (Abstract, p. 547)
1.2 Context - Source: "This study aims to examine students’ learning errors related to exponential expressions and to explore the underlying causes of these errors." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)

2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The study investigates the potential of generative AI-based chatbots... to identify students’ misconceptions regarding exponential expressions and to guide them in correcting these misconceptions." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
2.2 Description of context: Chatbots analyze student responses and provide feedback based on misconceptions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Students were asked to share their solutions for each question with AI-supported chatbots and to proceed based on the feedback they received from the bots." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)
2.3 Our evaluation: The chatbots provide varying levels of effective guidance, with ChatGPT-4 generally outperforming Gemini in classifying responses.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "ChatGPT demonstrated a higher level of accuracy in classifying student responses compared to the Gemini system." (Findings, p. 564)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students interact with chatbots for feedback.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The study seeks to assess whether students, without direct teacher support, can recognize and potentially correct their misconceptions with the help of chatbots." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; feedback is provided after responses.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students were asked to share their solutions for each question with AI-supported chatbots and to proceed based on the feedback they received from the bots." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Classification of student responses into categories such as correct knowledge, lack of confidence, lack of knowledge, and misconception.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The classification criteria for student responses were developed by considering the potential types of responses students might give." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)

Title: Constraint Based Student Modelling in Probability Story Problems with Scaffolding Techniques
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting for probability story problems.
1.2 Context - Source: "MAST is a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Section 4, page 181)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) utilizing Constraint-Based Modeling (CBM).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "Constraint-Based student Modeling (CBM) is an important technique employed in intelligent tutoring systems to model student knowledge to provide relevant assistance." (Abstract, page 178)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "This paper introduces the Math Story Problem Tutor (MAST), a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Section 1, page 179)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "MAST exploits both scaffolding questions and scaffolding feedback." (Section 7, page 181)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through highlighting keywords and scaffolding questions to guide students in solving probability problems.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "MAST provides different levels of feedback. It starts by presenting a clue to the student by highlighting the related violated constraint keywords that may be misinterpreted by the student." (Section 7.2, page 194)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is designed to be specific and targeted, helping students identify and correct their misunderstandings effectively.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "MAST introduces visual hints to the student in addition to the general feedback." (Section 7.2, page 195)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present through self-paced learning and the ability to request hints.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The student may display the sample space elements in textual form instead of in graphical form." (Section 7.1, page 194)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students can control when they receive feedback by submitting answers and requesting hints.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "In case of an error in the event set representation question, the student may request help by requesting a hint." (Section 7.2, page 195)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, Mann-Whitney U test, and power learning curves.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The tutoring effect of MAST has been evaluated empirically using different tests (paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, Mann-Whitney U test, and power learning curves)." (Abstract, page 178)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through student logs regarding their interactions with the system, including the types of problems selected and the assistance requested.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "A student model database stores all the student logs regarding the selected problem types and the presented statements." (Section 6, page 192)

Title: Enhancing Students ' Preparation for Math Exams Using the Advanced Features of the Halomda Platform
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the goal is to discuss how to enhance students’ self-preparation for math exam" (Introduction, page 1).
1.2 Context - Source: "students' preparation for mathematics exams is very important" (Introduction, page 1).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "the Halomda platform provides students with active feedback during the solution of the current task" (Section 3, page 24).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The Halomda platform (halomda.org) was established in 1988 in Israel" (Section 2, page 23).
1.5 Education level - Source: "students often read rapidly to cover as much material as possible" (Introduction, page 1).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the system provides different type of comments in a case of wrong answer" (Section 3, page 24).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided during problem-solving, with options for students to receive help from AI or other tools.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "the system proposes the students to get some advice from ChatGPT" (Section 3, page 24).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is interactive and aims to enhance understanding rather than just providing correct answers.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "active feedback from the system, together with the built-in tool, contributes to the sustainability of students’ knowledge" (Section 3, page 25).
3.1 Agency type: Self-directed learning agency.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "students have two options – recall the integration by parts formula using ChatGPT" (Section 4, page 25).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students can control when they receive feedback during their problem-solving process.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "students receive various type of help or are forced to select a result" (Section 4, page 25).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Improvement in self-efficacy and exam performance.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "leading to a subsequent enhancement of their self-efficacy in mathematics" (Introduction, page 1).

Title: Using Large Language Models to Diagnose Math Problem Solving Skills at Scale
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "We recruited 55 K3, 45 K4, 46 K5, and 39 K6 students and asked them to solve the problems based on the PERC framework." (Section 3, page 473)
1.2 Context - Source: "We focus on diagnosing the problem-solving skills of elementary school math word problems." (Section 1, page 471)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a large language model (LLM) pipeline that diagnoses students’ problem-solving skills from their answers at scale in elementary school math word problems." (Section 1, page 471)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Using GPT-3.5, our pipeline first generates the PERC rubrics for the given math word problem and uses them to diagnose students’ mathematical problem-solving competencies based on their answers." (Section 4.1, page 472)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We developed a problem-solving framework and an LLM pipeline to scaffold and diagnose four primary skills in mathematical problem-solving for elementary school students." (Section 2, page 472)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "We aim to push it further by diagnosing students’ answers to each stage and giving personalized feedback with LLMs." (Section 4, page 473)
2.2 Description of context: The feedback is generated based on the diagnosis of students' answers using a rubric.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The last module provides feedback based on the diagnosis result." (Section 4.1.3, page 473)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is tailored to the specific competencies assessed through the PERC framework.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "According to the combination, our pipeline gives feedback predefined by the math education expert." (Section 4.1.3, page 473)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is provided based on the model's diagnosis.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The module diagnoses the student’s mathematical competency and provides binary judgments (i.e., 1 for pass and 0 for fail) for each PERC competency." (Section 4.1.2, page 472)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified." (Not specified)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy of diagnosis results compared to expert grading.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The results... demonstrate that our pipeline outperformed baseline models in accuracy according to expert evaluation." (Section 4.2.2, page 473)

Title: Stimulating Individual Learning of the Concept of Fraction Equivalence
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants were 300 sixth-grade students from secondary schools in Germany." (Method, page 5)
1.2 Context - Source: "The study was conducted at the beginning of the school year 2022/2023." (Method, page 5)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "The experimental group used an adaptive digital learning environment for practice." (Method, page 5)
1.4 Tool/Platform: Not specified by name, but refers to a digital learning environment designed for fraction equivalence.
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The digital learning environment offers three tasks that progressively practice the formal procedure of expanding and reducing." (Method, page 6)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The instruction of equivalent fractions in our study is grounded in Bruner’s (1960) theory on the levels of representation." (Method, page 5)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "Immediate individualized feedback and adaptive adjustment of task difficulty can provide cognitive relief and prevent cognitive overload." (Discussion, page 14)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided based on students' performance in real-time, adjusting task difficulty and offering explanations for errors.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback is based on scientific recommendations... which include a combination of positive reinforcement and explanatory feedback." (Method, page 6)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is intended to enhance understanding and engagement, but its effectiveness varies among students.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The results of the present study partly support this claim." (Discussion, page 14)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present through the ability to engage with tasks at their own pace and choose difficulty levels.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students who are permitted to act in a self-determined and autonomous manner... tend to experience a sense of autonomy." (Discussion, page 14)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have some control over when they receive feedback based on their interactions with the tasks.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The digital learning environment... allows students to engage with the learning environment for genuine practice." (Method, page 5)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores on tasks, engagement metrics derived from process data.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We utilized process data to operationalize a combined measure of behavioral and cognitive engagement." (Method, page 5)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through students' self-reported perceptions of competence and autonomy support.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "We operationalized students’ motivational and emotional orientations regarding mathematics in general as a trait assessment with self-reports." (Method, page 6)

Title: Enhancing Formative Assessment in Statistics Through Classroom Action Research
1.1 Primary Stakeholders: Students and instructors in a higher education statistics class.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The formative assessments developed were administered asynchronously, where students were initially given 7 days to answer each activity at their convenience." (Methods and action plan section, page 386)
1.2 Context: Higher education statistics class during the COVID-19 pandemic.
1.2 Context - Source: "This study is rooted in my multi-disciplinary three-unit statistics class at a private higher education institution in the Philippines." (Context of the study section, page 382)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "One of the web-based technologies is the Learning Management System (LMS), which is intended to improve education delivery by assisting instructors in managing activities online." (Introduction section, page 382)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We opted for adopting MyOpenMath as our platform primarily because it has all the functions we needed." (Methods and action plan section, page 386)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The class has 33 student participants, 19 males and 14 females, with an average age of 18.54." (Methods and action plan section, page 386)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "We deemed it necessary to incorporate immediate feedback per item in the formative assessment that we were designing." (Action implementation: formative assessment development section, page 388)
2.2 Description of context: Formative assessments were delivered asynchronously through the LMS, allowing students to practice statistical exercises and receive immediate feedback on their answers.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Using LMS allowed me to administer formative assessments that can be automatically administered, retrieved, and graded." (Context of the study section, page 383)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided was immediate and aimed to correct misconceptions, which aligns with the purpose of formative assessment.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The immediate feedback setup of our formative assessment did not only serve to inform students about their scores, but it became a stimulus for them to take risks, identify their mistakes, and challenge them to get the correct answer." (Results and discussion section, page 390)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency in managing their learning through multiple attempts and asynchronous assessments.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "A student mentioned that she ‘doesn’t feel any pressure when answering the assessment’, because she can ‘always try again even if a mistake is committed’." (Results and discussion section, page 390)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Yes, students controlled the timing of feedback by choosing when to attempt assessments.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The formative assessment allowed students to assess themselves and find ways to improve in the course." (Reflection and insights section, page 391)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Student reflections, average number of attempts, and time spent on assessments.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We note the average number of attempts and average time students spent per attempt in the formative assessments through the data analytics of MyOpenMath." (Results and discussion section, page 390)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency was measured through student reflections and their ability to manage their assessment attempts.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Students expressed that they appreciate that they can partially answer the activity, take a break, and return to where they left off." (Results and discussion section, page 390)

Title: Improving the Validity of Automatically Generated Feedback via Reinforcement Learning
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The questions and feedback messages are written by real math teachers, deployed to real students..." (Section 4.1, page 286)
1.2 Context - Source: "We validate our framework using a dataset of middle school-level math multiple choice questions from Eedi..." (Section 4.1, page 286)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Large language models (LLMs) and reinforcement learning (RL).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a framework for automated feedback generation and evaluation via LLMs for students’ incorrect answers..." (Abstract, page 280)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We primarily focus on using Llama 2 7B Chat model... We also show that GPT-4 can evaluate feedback rather accurately..." (Section 4.3, page 287)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We validate our framework using a dataset of middle school-level math multiple choice questions..." (Section 4.1, page 286)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "For example, identifying student misconceptions, providing hints, and using encouraging language to promote a growth mindset..." (Introduction, page 281)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated for incorrect student responses to math questions, evaluated for correctness and alignment with educational goals.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "We propose a framework that both generates and evaluates feedback messages for incorrect student responses to questions..." (Abstract, page 280)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback generated is aimed at being pedagogically valid and aligned with educational goals, focusing on correctness and student misconceptions.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Feedback content has to be valid especially in subjects like math, which requires models to understand the problem, the solution, and where the student’s error lies." (Introduction, page 281)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is provided automatically without student control over timing.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "However, doing so is challenging since generated feedback should satisfy a wide variety of requirements..." (Introduction, page 281)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified; students do not control feedback timing.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Providing students with helpful feedback can be critical to their learning..." (Introduction, page 281)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Rubric scores based on correctness, revealing, suggestion, diagnostic, and positive aspects.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We aim to evaluate feedback messages on their alignment with educational goals, including those associated with a growth mindset..." (Section 3.1, page 283)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Not specified; no direct measurement of agency is mentioned.
